TextView.android:text: When a function f ( x ) is differentiated to yield the derivative f ′ ( x ) , this derivative is itself a function of x and satisfies all the required properties of a function of x . One property that it satisfies is that it can itself be differentiated. Differentiating f ( x ) a further time with respect to x yields what is called the second derivative, written as f ′′ ( x ) or d 2 f d x 2 . Sometimes f ′ ( x ) is called the ''first'' derivative to distinguish it from the second derivative. It is sometimes convenient to describe the second derivative as the rate of change of the first derivative. The actual differentiation used to find the second derivative is carried out in the same way as the differentiation used to find the first derivative. The second derivative can be differentiated once more to form the third derivative, denoted by f ′′′ ( x ) or d 3 f d x 3 . Similarly, the third derivative can be differentiated to give the ''fourth'' derivative f 4 ( x ) . Note the use of the 4 in brackets to avoid the use of four dashes which could easily be miscounted. For many functions, differentiation can be carried out indefinitely..
